question.name: 23.2.4.1 Examples of Fourier series
question.questiontext:
Examples of Fourier series

We shall obtain the Fourier series of the \half-rectified" square wave shown in the Figure below.




We have \[ f(t) = \begin{cases} 1 \hspace{1cm} 0 < t < \pi \\ 0 \hspace{1cm} \pi < t < 2\pi \end{cases} \] \[f(t + 2\pi) = f(t) \] The calculation of the Fourier coefficients is merely a straightforward integration using the results already obtained: \[ a_n = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \displaystyle{ \int_{-\pi}^\pi } f(t) \cos nt \hspace{0.15cm}dt \] in general. Hence, for our square wave \[ a_n = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \displaystyle{ \int_{0}^\pi } (1) \cos nt \hspace{0.15cm}dt = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \left[ \dfrac{\sin nt}{n} \right] _0 ^\pi = 0 \] provided \( n \neq 0\).

But \( a_0 = \dfrac{1}{\pi}\displaystyle{ \int_{0}^\pi } (1) \hspace{0.15cm}dt = 1\), so the constant term is \( \dfrac{a_0}{2} = \dfrac{1}{2} \).

(The square wave takes on values \(1\) and \(0\) over equal length intervals of \(t\) so \( \dfrac{1}{2}\) is clearly the mean value.)

Similarly \[ b_n = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \displaystyle{ \int_{0}^\pi } (1) \sin nt \hspace{0.15cm}dt = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \left[ \dfrac{-\cos nt}{n} \right] _0 ^\pi \] Some care is needed now! \[ b_n = \dfrac{1}{n\pi}(1 - \cos n\pi)\] But \[ \begin{align} \cos n\pi = +1 \hspace{1cm} \text{ for } \hspace{1cm} &n = 2, 4, 6, \dots \\ \therefore b_n = 0 \hspace{1cm} \text{ for } \hspace{1cm} &n = 2, 4, 6, \dots \end{align} \] However \[ \begin{align} \cos n\pi = -1 \hspace{1cm} \text{ for } \hspace{1cm} &n = 1, 3, 5, \dots \\ \therefore b_n = \dfrac{1}{n\pi}(1 - (-1)) = \dfrac{2}{n\pi} \hspace{1cm} \text{ for } \hspace{1cm} &n = 1, 3, 5, \dots \end{align} \] i.e \(b_1 = \dfrac{2}{\pi}\), \(b_3 = \dfrac{2}{3\pi}\), \(b_5 = \dfrac{2}{5\pi}\), \(\dots\)

Hence the required Fourier series is \[ \begin{align} f(t) &= \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n = 1} ^\infty (a_n\cos nt + b_n \sin nt ) \hspace{1cm} \text{in general} \\ f(t) &= \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left(\sin t + \dfrac{1}{3}\sin 3t + \dfrac{1}{5}\sin 5t + \dots \right) \hspace{1cm} \text{in this case} \end{align} \] Note that the Fourier series for this particular form of the square wave contains a constant term and odd harmonic sine terms. We already know why the constant term arises (because of the non-zero mean value of the functions) and will explain later why the presence of any odd harmonic sine terms could have been predicted without integration.

The Fourier series we have found can be written in summation notation in various ways:

For odd values of \(n\) we have \[ \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \sum _{n=1}^\infty \dfrac{1}{n} \sin nt \] or, since \(n\) is odd, we may rewrite \( n = 2k - 1\), \(k = 1,2 \dots \) and write the Fourier series as \[ \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \dfrac{1}{2k - 1} \sin (2k -1) t \]
